direction.raw_text: The walls are covered with commendation, photos of Mulwray at various construction sites, large maps of watershed areas and reservoirs in the city. On the desk is a framed, tinted photo of Evelyn in riding clothes. Gittes moves to the desk, watching the translucent pane in the upper half of the door leading to the outer office as he does. He begins to open and close the desk drawers after quickly examining the top. He tries one of the drawers and it doesn't open. He reopens the top drawer, and the bottom one opens. He looks in it, pulls out a checkbook. He opens it, riffles through the stubs like he was shuffling cards. Drops it, finds a set of keys, an old phone book, and a menu from a Water Department lunch at the Biltmore Hotel in 1913. Then, He flips through them, reads one notation in Mulwray's neat hand: "Tues. night. Oak Pass Res. 7 channels used." Gittes spots a shadow looming in front of the translucent pane. He quickly tosses item after item back, kneeing the drawer, nearly knocking a spare pair of Mulwray's glasses off the desk top when he does. He catches them, puts them on the desk and is pacing the room as the door opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enters the room. An anxious Secretary is right behind him.

result.heading: "OWN YOUR OWN OFFICE IN THIS BUILDING

direction.raw_text: Gittes can see the muddy remains of a collapsed shack, its contents strewn down river from the bridge. Below him, lying half over the storm drain and one wall that was on the bank of the river is a sign that proclaims "OWN YOUR OWN OFFICE IN THIS BUILDING $5000 to $6000" which was used as a roof of sorts. Downstream, there's the dresser, an oil drum, a Ford seat cushion, an Armour lard can, etc. The trashy remains of Shuhardt's home. Gittes scrambles down the embankment and as he lands near the storm drain one shoe sinks, ankle deep into mud. Gittes pulls it out, swearing. He begins to walk a little further downstream when he hears the vaguely familiar SQUISHY CLOP of something. Clearing the bridge on the opposite side is the little Mexican Boy, again on his swayback horse, riding along the muddy bank. They look at one another a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Boy nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The shadows of the two are very long now.

direction.raw_text: . RIVERBED  DUSK Gittes scrambles up the embankment to note the direction the storm drain by Hollenbeck Bridge takes. It is headed above toward the Hollywood Hills, where the sun is setting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Winding his way up a section of the Hollywood Hills. He picks up on an open flood channel with the spotlight by the driver's windwing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Along the flood channel. It is dark now and Gittes follows the channel with the car spotlight. He turns at a fork in the road which allows him to continue following the flood channel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The road is narrower. Gittes drives more slowly. Foliage is overgrown in the channel so its bottom cannot be glimpsed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The road is dirt. Heavy clusters of oak trees and eucalyptus are everywhere. It is very still. Another turn and a pie- shaped view of a lake of lights in the city below can be GLIMPSED.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CHAIN-LINK FENCE Over the road, bolted. It says "OAK PASS RESERVOIR. KEEP OUT. NO TRESPASSING." The chain-link itself actually extends over the flood channel and down into it, making access along the channel itself impossible. Gittes backs up, turns off the motor, the car lights, the spotlight. A lone light overhead on tension wires is the sole illumination. There is only the eerie SOUND of the tension WIRES HUMMING. Gittes gets out of the car, clubs the fence near the Flood channel itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes carefully works his way up through the thick Foliage toward a second and large chain-link fence. Lights from the reservoir still higher above can be SEEN. Suddenly there is a GUNSHOT. Then ANOTHER. Gittes dives into the flood control channel, which is at this point about four feet deep and six feet wide. There is the SOUND of men scurrying through the brush, coming near him, then retreating. Gittes loses himself among the ivy in the channel. He waits. The men seem to have passed him by. But there is another SOUND now. An echoing growing sound. It puzzles Gittes. He starts to lift his head to catch the direction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he's inundated with a rush of water which pours over him, knocks off his hat, carries him down the channel, banging into its banks, as he desperately tries to grab some of the overgrowth to hang on and pull himself out. But the force of the stream batters him and carries him with it until he's brought rudely to the chainlink fence. It stops him cold. He's nearly strained through it. Swearing and choking, he pulls himself out of the rushing water by means of the fence itself. Drenched, battered, he slowly climbs back over the fence and makes his way toward his car.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: GITTES IN FLOOD CONTROL CHANNEL NIGHT

direction.raw_text: Gittes, driven in a station wagon, passes under the sign with a cross painted below the name. The ranch itself is only partially in a valley on the island. As the wagon continues one can SEE that it is actually a miniature California, encompassing desert, mountains and canyon that tumble down palisades to the windward side of the sea. The wagon comes to a halt where a group of hands are clustered around a corral. The circle of men drift apart, leaving JULIAN CROSS standing, using a cane for support, reedy but handsome in a rough linen shirt and jeans. When he talks his strong face is lively, in repose it looks ravaged.

dialogue.raw_text: Too bad?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It disturbs me, Mr. Gittes. It makes me think you're taking my daughter for a ride. Financially speaking, of course. How much are you charging her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (carefully) My usual fee, plus a bonus if I come up with any results.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sleeping with her? Come, come, Mr. Gittes. You don't have to think about that to remember, do you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you want an answer to that question I can always put one of my men on the job. Good afternoon, Mr. Cross.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gittes!  You're dealing with a disturbed woman who's lost her husband. I don't want her taken advantage of. Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may think you know what you're dealing with, but believe me, you don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why is that funny?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's what the D.A. used to tell me about Chinatown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was he right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) ...Exactly what do you know about me, Mr. Gittes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mainly that you're rich and too respectable to want your name in the papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grunts, then) 'Course I'm respectable. I'm old. Politicians, ugly buildings and whores all get respectable if they last long enough. I'll double whatever your fees are and I'll pay you ten thousand dollars if you can find Hollis' girlfriend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His girlfriend?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, his girlfriend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean the little chippie he was with at the El Macando?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. She's disappeared, hasn't she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doesn't that strike you as odd?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. She's probably scared to death.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wouldn't it be useful to talk to her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If Mulwray was murdered, she was probably one of the last people to see him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't see Mulwray much, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When was the last time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sheriff's gold posse... bunch of damn fools who pay $5,000 apiece to the sheriff's reelection. I let 'em practice up out here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Do you remember the last time you talked to Mulwray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At my age, you tend to lose track...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, It was about five days ago. You were outside the Pig 'n Whistle and you had one hell of an argument.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) I've got the photographs in my office. If they'll help you remember. What was the argument about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a long pause, then:) My daughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just find the girl, Mr. Gittes. I think she is frightened and I happen to know Hollis was fond of her. I'd like to help her if I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't realize you and Hollis were so fond of each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hollis Mulwray made this city and he made me a fortune... We were a lot closer than Evelyn realized.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you want to hire me, I still have to know what you and Mulwray were arguing about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (painfully) Well... she's an extremely jealous person. I didn't want her to find out about the girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you find out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've still got a few teeth in my head, Mr. Gittes, and a few friends in town.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. My secretary'll send you a letter of agreement. Tell me are you worried about that girl, or what Evelyn might do to her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just find the girl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll look into it as soon as I check out some avocado groves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Avocado groves?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll be in touch, Mr. Cross.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HALL OF RECORDS  DAY Dark and quiet except for the whirring of fans. Gittes approaches one of the CLERKS at a desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Clerk's droopy eyes widen a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which is a snotty remark. Gittes smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Clerk turns away abruptly. Gittes regards his back a moment, then goes to the stacks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a little lost. Where can I find the plat books for the northwest valley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Part of it's in Ventura County. We don't have Ventura County in our Hall of Records.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll settle for L.A. County.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (regards him, then) Row twenty-three, section C.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gittes sees the Clerk turn to another, say something. The second clerk gets on the phone. Gittes watches a moment, then swiftly turns his attention to the stacks. He hauls down the northwest valley volume, opens it. It's huge and there's a lot to go through. The print itself makes him squint.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PAGE Showing TRACT, LOT, PARCEL, even a METES AND BOUNDS designation where the description of the land parcel is long and hopelessly involved e.g. '6000 paces to Rio Seco, thence 7000 paces to Loma Linda, etc.' These descriptions are old and faded. In the owners' column, however there are numerous freshly typed names pasted over the prior owners.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Clerk turns sharply around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks a little surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The exasperated Clerk reaches around, rummages, slaps a ruler on the desk. Gittes goes back to the stacks with the ruler. He opens the book, places the ruler not horizontally but vertically.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hauls the huge volume back to the Clerk's desk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Clerk) Say... uh... sonny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How come all these new names are pasted into the plat book?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Land sales out of escrow are always recorded within the week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then these are all new owners?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (astonished) But that means that most of the valley's been sold in the last few months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If that's what it says.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can I check one of these volumes out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly snotty) Sir, this is not a lending library, it's the Hall of Records.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, how about a ruler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A ruler?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The print's pretty fine. I forgot my glasses. I'd like to be able to read across.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: PLAT BOOK NORTHWEST VALLEY Beside the OWNER column he places the ruler, looks toward the clerks, then swiftly rips down the page, tearing out a strip about two inches wide containing the owner's name and property description. As he tears, he either sniffles or coughs to cover the SOUND of the PAPER being ripped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ROAD  GITTES DRIVING  DAY Amidst a hall of shimmering dust and heat, parched and drying groves, narrower roads. He passes a ramshackle home, next to a rotting orchard. There is a "SOLD" sign on the collapsing barn. Gittes stops, checks it against the names he had taken from the Hall of Records.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a few withered pepper trees. Gittes has paused at this dried-up intersection. There is a "SOLD" sign on a drug store. Gittes looks OFF SCREEN. Coming INTO VIEW above the arid fields is a spiraling cloud of purple smoke. Gittes heads in that direction. Gittes parks at the edge of the field. About twenty yards away is a man mounted on a strange machine, holding a lid off it. Billowing lavender clouds are belching forth. Several CHILDREN are watching the man at work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes nods, walks over to the man who is elaborately busying himself with the intricacies of his machine. He's aware of Gittes watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Rainmaker now glances down at Gittes, who as usual is immaculately dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Rainmaker steps down.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to one of the Children) Say, pal, what's he doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Making some rain.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're just the man I'm looking for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some associates and I are thinking of buying property out here. Of course, we're worried about the rainfall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No problem with me on the Job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. (glancing around at the desolate, dry field) Do you have any references?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & GITTES RAINMAKER City of La Habra Heights filled an 800,000 gallon reservoir with sixteen inches of rain in two days.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (nods) That's swell. But how about here? (pulling out names from his pocket) Ever worked for Robert Knox, Emma Dill, Clarence Speer, Marian Parsons, or Jasper Lamar Crabb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never heard of 'em... new owners?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (climbing back up) Lot of turnover these days. Better tell them to get in touch with me if they want to hang onto their land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I'll do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Is now covered with a film of dust: He reaches a fork in the dirt road. There are a couple of mailboxes. Gittes takes this fork and begins a slow ascent. As he does, the tops of a line of bright green trees can be SEEN, coming more and more INTO VIEW, row upon row of avocado and walnut groves, their foliage heavy. The few structures in the distance are white-washed, and well kept, right down to the white-washed stones that mark the pathway to the home. Towering above it all is a huge wooden water tank. Gittes drives through a gate that has "NO TRESPASSING" and "KEEP OUT PRIVATE PROPERTY" signs neatly printed on it. He drives down the road into the grove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulls to a halt in the road flanking the orchard lanes. He puts the car in neutral, stares at the trees. By contrast with what he has seen they are lush and beautiful, their heavy branches barely swaying in a light breeze. Then a SHOTGUN BLAST abruptly strips bare the branches of the tree he'd been staring at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AVOCADO GROVES  DAY Gittes is shocked. He looks behind him. Riding on horseback down the field in the direction he had just driven is a Red- Faced Man in overalls. His hat blows off his head. He does not, however, lose the shotgun he has just used. Gittes' lane of retreat is denied him. He guns the car, and takes off down one of the orchard lanes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dirt lane is rough. As Gittes nears the end of it, a Younger Man on a mule blocks the exit. Gittes veers a sharp left, knocking a branch off one of the trees, heading down one of the cross-lanes. Here he's pursued by a scraggly dog that nips at the tires. Gittes yells at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two farmers on foot, one using a crutch, run down the lanes toward a dust trail rising above the trees. They've spotted it. Clearly it's from Gittes' car. This hide-and-seek chase between one man on horseback, one on a mule and a couple on foot continues up and down and across the orchard lanes until Gittes' front tire and radiator are ruptured by another SHOTGUN BLAST. Gittes' car veers off, scattering a stray gaggle of geese and smacks into an avocado tree, shaking loose a barrage of the heavy fruit onto Gittes and the car. Gittes immediately tries to get out through the branches over the back of his car, but he's pulled off it by one of the younger farmers, a huge brute who he begins to tussle with. The Crippled Farmer begins to bang Gittes on the back with his crutch. The two of them manage to pound Gittes to the ground within moments, where the Crippled Farmer continues to whack away at Gittes with the crutch. The older Red Faced Farmer with the shotgun and the Man on a mule ride up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes is hefted half off the ground and the two younger Farmers spin him around, going through his clothes. Gittes is badly banged up and half out on his feet. They toss his wallet, his silver cigarette case, etc. on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes leans against the back of his car, breathing heavily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes' back is to the Red Faced Farmer. He has trouble catching his breath. The Crippled Farmer pokes him rudely in the back with his crutch. Gittes turns sharply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks up at the Red Faced Farmer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes reaches into his pocket. The paper's on the ground. He picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Big Farmer takes a swing at Gittes. Gittes kicks him squarely in the nuts, knees him in the jaw after he's doubled up, and hits him solidly. The Crippled Farmer takes careful aim and brings his crutch down on the back of Gittes' head. Gittes is knocked to the ground and lies still beside the Big Farmer who is writhing in agony in the dirt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, quit it! Quit now! Search the man, see if he's armed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said see if he's armed, not empty his pockets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He ain't armed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, mister. Who you with? Water department or the real estate office?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Crippled Farmer) Get away from me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Answer him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Touch me with that thing again and you'll need a pair of them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shoving Gittes) Whyn't you pick on somebody your own size?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said cut that out! Give him a chance to say something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reaching down for his wallet) Name's Gittes. I'm a private investigator and I'm not with either one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then what are you doing out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Client hired me to see... whether or not the water department's been irrigating your land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Irrigating my land? (exploding) The water department's been sending you people to blow up my water tanks! They threw poison down three of my wells! I call that a funny way to irrigate. Who'd hire you for a thing like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Evelyn Mulwray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mulwray? That's the son of a bitch who's done it to us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mulwray's dead. You don't know what you're talking about, you dumb Oakie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: There's a PURLING SOUND, which soon becomes defined into the SOUND OF VOICES talking quietly  about whether to move or not to move, doctors, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: EVELYN MULWRAY Is staring down at Gittes who's lying in the screened in porch of the farmers. His wife, the Red Faced Farmer, and the Big Farmer are there, along with the dog. The Red Faced Farmer's wife has set tea out. The farmers, all of them, now seem awkward and a little embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He focuses on Evelyn who sits right next to him. He's got dried blood down the side of his face from his nose, a huge mouse on his cheek, and his clothes are torn in a couple of spots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes nods. He checks his watch. He looks out. It's almost evening. Gittes says nothing. The wife of the Red Faced Farmer (DUBOIS) looks reproachfully at Dubois. Gittes feels the back of his head, It obviously hurts him.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: FRONT PORCH RED FACE FARMER'S HOUSE REACTION GITTES DUSK
result.heading: FRONT PORCH RED FACE FARMER'S HOUSE REACTION GITTES DUSK

dialogue.raw_text: (to Evelyn) What's going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, almost as if he were in a hospital) You didn't look too good, so we thought we better call your employer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DUBOIS FARMHOUSE  EVENING Evelyn and Gittes go out to her car, the cream colored Packard. Dubois accompanies them, along with the Big Farmer who is carrying a crate of something. Gittes has cleaned himself up a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks. Earl has the huge crate he's holding brim-full of avocados.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look here, if it's all the same with you, we'll get your car patched up. If you'll tell me what your trousers run you, I'll make good on them, Mr. Gittes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay, Mr. Dubois.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Evelyn) It's just that they're after everybody out here, tearing up our irrigation ditches trying to make our land worthless so they can pick it up for twenty-five dollars an acre.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Anyway. Earl here is sorry, too. He wants to give you something to take back with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks, Earl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & GITTES  DUSK Evelyn driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes pulls out cigarette case, takes one, offers one to Evelyn who refuses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's pulling out his wallet, excitedly now, spilling its contents onto the seat. He pulls out the obituary column he'd folded up earlier in the day.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for coming...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That dam is a con job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What dam?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one your husband opposed. They're conning L.A. into building it, only the water won't go to L.A. It'll go here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Valley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everything you can see, everything around us. I was at the Hall of Records today. (whips out papers, turns on the car light) That bother you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking over papers) In the last three months, Robert Knox has bought 7,000 acres, Emma Dill 12,000 acres, Clarence Speer 5,000 acres, and Jasper Lamar Crabb 25,000 acres.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jasper Lamar Crabb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I think I'd remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. They've been blowing these farmers out of here and buying their land for peanuts. Have any idea what this land'll be worth with a steady water supply? About thirty million more than they paid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Hollis knew about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's why he was killed. Jasper Lamar Crabb. Jasper Lamar Crabb.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) We got it. We got it, baby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There was a memorial service at the Mar Vista Inn today for Jasper Lamar Crabb. He died three weeks ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that unusual?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two weeks ago he bought those 25,000 acres. That's unusual.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT
result.heading: MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME  NIGHT Evelyn's car pulls up before the elegant Spanish rest home, its entryway illuminated by streetlights. There is a small sign giving the name of the place in elegant neon scroll. It sits on the rolling green lawns. Gittes gets out of the car with Evelyn. He offers her his arm and they go up the walkway to the entrance.
direction.name: direction

result.ToD: MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT
result.heading: MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME NIGHT

direction.raw_text: . MAR VISTA INN AND REST HOME  NIGHT Gittes and Evelyn are approached by an unctuous man in his forties, with a flower in his buttonhole. He sees Evelyn first.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he gets a clear look at Gittes, bruised, trousers torn, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn can't quite conceal her surprise at the question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn stares back at Gittes, amused and appalled. She manages to nod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes locks eyes with Palmer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello there, I'm Mr. Palmer. Can I help you folks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I sure hope so. It's Dad. (indicating his disheveled appearance) I just can't handle him anymore, can I, sweetheart?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my goodness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hastily) Nothing to do with Dad. It's me, actually.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They just don't get along very well. Dad's a lamb with anyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not so sure) Oh, well, I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naturally, I want the best for him, money is no object.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps if we could meet your father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's just one question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you accept anyone of the Jewish persuasion?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (very embarrassed) I'm sorry. We don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smoothly) Don't be sorry, neither does Dad. Wanted to make sure though, didn't we, honey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just to be certain, I wonder if you could show us a list of your patients?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (polite but pointed) We don't reveal the names of our guests as a matter of policy. I know you'd appreciate that if your father came to live with us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (confidentially) That's exactly what we wanted to hear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder, is it too late for us to have a look around?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think so. Be happy to show you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would you mind if we took a stroll on our own?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just, if you will, confine yourself to the main building. It's nearly bedtime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We understand, c'mon, sweetheart.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking. Either by accident or design, the primarily octogenarian guests have segregated themselves. In one wing, the men are playing pinochle, some are playing dominoes, one elderly gentleman sits by himself carefully peeling an orange. In an adjacent parlor several white-headed ladies work on a quilt. Gittes grabs Evelyn's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes points to the wall. It says "ACTIVITIES BOARD". There are titles. "LAWN BOWLING". "BRIDGE". "FISHING". "CROQUET". Below them are the names of the guests, entered under certain activities, for certain days. After Evelyn looks, she turns to Gittes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes strolls toward the women knitting and working on the quilt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two of the ladies giggle. The third continues to busy herself with her quilt, off by herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two of them say "she is," and point in different directions. The third gives them a curt look and goes back to her knitting. Gittes approaches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some old voice is singing softly, "Don't Sit Under the Apple Tree."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks at the quilt. In it is the head of a fish among the rest of the crazy quilt pattern. Gittes spots it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks through the quilt for other pieces of the fish, comes across the tail and by it the initials A.C.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks up, sees Palmer standing in the doorway, looking taut and a little drawn. Evelyn is beside him. She gestures as if there's someone behind Palmer. Gittes rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks toward Palmer who waits for him to walk in front.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly) They're all here. Every goddam name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing; indicating the ancients around them) You're looking at the owners of a 50,000 acre empire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (astonished) They can't be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They may not know it but they are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, girls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Which one of you is Emma Dill?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you Emma?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've been wanting to meet you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you know that you're a very wealthy woman?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stitching, smiles) I'm not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well you own a lot of land.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not anymore. Oh, some time ago, my late husband owned a good deal of beach property in Long Beach, but we lost it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's just lovely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating tail) Where did you get this material?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (what it sounds like) The apple core club.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The apple core?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. The albacore. It's a fish. My grandson's a member and they take very nice care of us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do they do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give us things. Not just some old flag like this, but -
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (kneeling) But what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're a sort of unofficial charity of theirs, Mr. Gittes. Would you care to come this way? Someone wants to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you later, Emma.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Is waiting. He's got his hand in his pocket. Evelyn looks to Gittes. The four of them stand there, Mulvihill towering over everyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mulvihill has walked up beside Gittes. He makes the mistake of opening the glass door in the entryway, putting his back to Gittes for a moment. Gittes swiftly pulls Mulvihill's jacket up over his head. He spins him around. With his jacket covering his face, Gittes hammers away at Mulvihlll, beating him against the glass door, along the wall, mercilessly pounding his fists into the cloth until the cloth turns red and Mulvihill begins to sink to the red tile floor. Palmer screams. Evelyn stands there astonished. Mulvihill's gun has clattered to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn goes. Mulvihill tries to get up again. Palmer starts to go for the gun, nearly picking it up. Gittes slaps it out of his hand and kicks it. It goes flying down the hall, at least thirty feet; hits the wall. Palmer goes screaming off into the night. Gittes turns back to Mulvihill who starts to get up, then collapses. Gittes goes out the front door, ignoring the excited audience of ancients behind him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on I want you to meet somebody, Gittes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (glancing from Palmer to Mulvihill) Can we leave the lady out of this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little uncertain) Yeah, why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, I'd like to walk her to her car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking her by the arm) Get in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll see she makes it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as Mulvihill hits the floor, to Evelyn) What are you waiting for? Get in the car!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As Gittes walks down the pathway, he stops. Two men are coming toward him. One of them is shorter, and has the nervous, jerky moves of the man who slit his nose. Gittes stops. The two men fan out and continue to move toward him. Gittes spots the two-tone shoes. He begins to back up. Suddenly there is a pair of headlights flashing brilliantly behind the two men. In a moment Evelyn's car is headed across the lawn directly toward the two men, accelerating as it gets near them. They look in disbelief, then dive for safety. The car skids to a stop, fishtailing a little on the grass. Evelyn opens the passenger door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes jumps in and she takes off across the lawn, tilting the elegant little neon sign on the lawn as she goes. Two SHOTS ARE FIRED.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & GITTES Evelyn looking straight ahead, driving. After a moment she takes one hand off the wheel and rubs her left eye a little. Gittes watches her. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . VERANDA  MULWRAY HOME  NIGHT Gittes stands on the veranda, smoking a cigarette, staring off into the night. Evelyn comes out to the veranda, carrying a tray with whiskey and an ice bucket on it. She sets it down. Gittes turns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes touches his nose, winces a little.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes looks sharply at her. Then:

direction.raw_text: She looks at him. Gittes stares off into the night. Evelyn has poured herself another drink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes gets up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He touches his nose lightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his hand and leads him back into the house.

dialogue.raw_text: (watching her pour) Maid's night off?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little surprised, he laughs) What do you mean, 'why?' Nobody's here, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing Gittes his drink) I gave everybody the night off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy, it's an innocent question.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No question from you is innocent, Mr. Gittes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) I guess not to you, Mrs. Mulwray. Frankly you really saved my a... my neck tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me something. Does this usually happen to you, Mr. Gittes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that, Mrs. Mulwray?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I'm only judging on the basis of one afternoon and an evening, but if that's how you go about your work, I'd say you're lucky to get through a whole day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pouring himself another drink) Actually this hasn't happened to me in some time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When was the last time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just. I don't know why. I'm asking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was in Chinatown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What were you doing there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking a long drink) Working for the District Attorney.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doing what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As little as possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The District Attorney gives his men advice like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do in Chinatown.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bothers you to talk about it, doesn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. I wonder... could I. Do you have any peroxide or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh sure. C'mon.

direction.raw_text: Gittes pulls the plaster off his nose, stares at it in the mirror. Evelyn takes some hydrogen peroxide and some cotton out of a medicine cabinet. Evelyn turns Gittes' head toward her. She has him sit on the pullman tile adjacent to the sink.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She begins to work on his nose with the peroxide. Then she sees his cheek, checks back in his hair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes shrugs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're very close now as she's going over a mouse very near his eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes hold of her and pulls her even closer,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes kisses her lightly, gradually rises until he's standing holding her. She hesitates, then wraps her arms around him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Doctor did a nice job...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Boy oh boy, you're a mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (working on him) So why does it bother you to talk about it... Chinatown...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bothers everybody who works there, but to me... It was...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hold still. Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't always tell what's going on there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...No. Why was it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought I was keeping someone from being hurt and actually I ended up making sure they were hurt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could you do anything about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. Make sure I don't find myself in Chinatown anymore. Wait a second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (momentarily freezing) What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (staring intently) There's something black in the green part of your eye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not moving) Oh that... It's a flaw in the iris...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...A flaw...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she almost shivers) ...Yes, sort of a birthmark...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: On a nightstand, city lights visible through the open window behind it. It is RINGING. Evelyn's arm reaches INTO SHOT. SOUND of something hitting the headboard. Gittes moans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes in bed, holding his head, which he's just hit. Evelyn pauses in her reach to the phone. She turns to him, whispers, "I'm sorry," kisses him on the head and lips. PHONE CONTINUES TO RING. She picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello... (in Spanish now) No, no, I'll come and help, just keep watching her and don't do anything until I get there... 'bye.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Gittes in bed, watching Evelyn next to him as she's talking on the phone. She hangs up. She touches Gittes' cheek lightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes stares at her silently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She leaps out of bed, throwing on a robe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn starts quickly for the bathroom, then comes back and kneels by the side of the bed, takes Gittes' hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him, rushes to the bathroom, shuts the door. Gittes stares at it a moment. Then leaps out of bed, rummages around, tosses on his trousers. He grabs his shoes, throws them on. Then hurries out of the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just... I have to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I want to know where.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she starts out of bed) Please don't be angry... believe me, it's got nothing to do with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping her) Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (near tears) Please!... Trust me this much... (she kisses him lightly) I'll be back. Look, there is something I should tell you. The fishing club that old lady mentioned, the pieces off the flag.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Albacore Club.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It has to do with my father.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He owns it. You know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting up straight) You saw my fa... father? When?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panicked) You didn't tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There hasn't been a lot of time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did he say? (insistent) What did he say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That you were jealous, and he was worried about what you might do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do? To who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mulwray's girlfriend, for one thing. He wanted to know where she was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to listen to me. My father is a very dangerous man. You don't know how dangerous. You don't know how crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me an example.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You may think you know what's going on, but you don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what your father said. You're telling me he's in back of this whole thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's possible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Including the death of your husband?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's possible. Please don't ask me any more questions now. Just wait, wait for me. I'll be back. I need you here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Running across the driveway to the garage. There are two cars there. Mulwray's Buick and Evelyn's Packard. Gittes moves over to the Buick, opens the passenger's door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Checks the ignition. No key is in it. He pulls a couple of wires from under the dash, starts to mess with them, seems satisfied. Slides out across the seat, slams the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MULWRAY DRIVEWAY  NIGHT Gittes hurries over to the Packard. He gets down on the driveway, lying on his back, bracing himself. With the heel of his shoe, he kicks at the right rear taillight of the car. He shatters the red lens, gets up. He carefully pulls the red lens off the taillight, exposing the white light beneath it. He tosses the red lens into the shrubbery and hurries back toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT Evelyn's car speeds along the curves on Sunset Boulevard, the red and white lights coming IN AND OUT OF VIEW.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Behind the wheel of Mulwray's car, keeping a healthy distance from Evelyn in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pulls up before a small little bungalow house. She gets out, looks up and down the street. There is nothing. She hurries on up the walkway to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Idles the engine with the lights off. He brings the car a few yards further down the street, parking it near Evelyn's. Gittes gets out of the car and goes up the walkway. The curtains are drawn except for one of the small windows on the side of the house. He goes to it and looks, balancing on the edge of the porch.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DOWN THE STREET GITTES IN BUICK

direction.raw_text: Gittes sees Evelyn's Oriental servant rush through the living room of the small house. In a moment he re-emerges back through the living room carrying a tray with a glass and pitcher on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Around to the side of the house. He runs into shrubbery and a short picket fence. He climbs over it, follows along the stucco wall to a series of windows at the corner of the house. These all have shades on them. He can hear someone crying in the house. Someone else talking alternately firmly and plaintively in Spanish. Here the windows have blinds. He moves to one where the blind is not completely drawn. There's an inch or so of space at the bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes can see the servant again. Evelyn is pacing back and forth in and out of his line of vision. After a moment someone rises INTO SHOT, obviously from lying on a bed. The figure is just a few feet from Evelyn. Her tear-stained face comes INTO VIEW. It is unmistakably the girl Gittes had last seen with Hollis Mulwray. Mulwray's girlfriend. She's looking up to Evelyn, speaking in Spanish. Her words are not discernible but the tone is bitter, anguished. A newspaper is strewn about the room. Evelyn kneels. She insists that the girl swallow down some pills. The girl reluctantly does.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Continues to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET  EVELYN  NIGHT Emerges from the house, goes to her car and gets in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn sees Gittes sitting in her car, staring coldly at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes starts to get out of the car. Evelyn grabs his arm, nearly screaming:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her intensity actually rips Gittes' already partially torn jacket. He looks at it and her. It seems to have a momentary calming effect on both of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes explodes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long pause. Evelyn's head sinks onto the steering wheel, her hair covering her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn is breathing very deeply now. Not crying, but the kind of deep breathing that comes from real hysteria. Gittes puts an arm on her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She lifts her head and looks up at him. He's genuinely puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods. Gittes sighs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She begins to cry softly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a long moment of silence. Gittes looks over to Evelyn. Her hair covers most of her face from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets out and slams the car door. She drives off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, give me the keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned, furious) You bastard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's either that or you drive to the police yourself.

dialogue.raw_text: The police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Mrs. Mulwray. You've got your husband's girlfriend tied up in there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know what I mean. You're keeping her there against her will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hollis' death. I tried to keep it from her, I didn't want her upset before I could make plans for her to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean she just found out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what it looks like, Mrs. Mulwray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does it look like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like she knows about Hollis' death. Like she knows more than you want her to tell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're insane.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just tell me the truth. I'm not the police. I don't care what you've done. I'm not going to hurt you, but one way or another I'm going to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You won't go to the police if I tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will if you don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's my sister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it easy... If it's your sister it's your sister... why all the secrecy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (really upset) I can't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because of Hollis? Because she was seeing your husband? Was that it? Jesus Christ, say something. Was that it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) I would never ever have harmed Hollis. I loved him more than my own family. He was the most gentle, decent man imaginable... and he put up with more from me than you'll ever know... I just wanted him to be happy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a moment) I took your husband's Buick... (he opens the car door) I'll return it tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't you coming back with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. I'm not telling anybody about this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...That's not what I meant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) Yeah, well... I'm very tired, Mrs. Mulwray. Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The spray is hitting him full on the top of the head. Gittes is so exhausted he's literally holding onto the nozzle as the water pours down. He shuts the shower off, reaches weakly for a towel, dabs his nose lightly with it.

result.heading: CERRITOS TOWER ROAD HOLLYWOOD HILLS EARLY MORNING

direction.raw_text: . CERRITOS TOWER ROAD  HOLLYWOOD HILLS  EARLY MORNING Gittes pulls up. It is a bungalow courtyard with a very narrow walkway and sickly green stucco.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . IDA SESSIONS' APARTMENT  DAY Gittes at the front door. It's slightly ajar. He knocks. Nothing. He opens it and enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morning light filters through the half-open blinds. Dust particles in the shafts of light. It's still and empty. Gittes sees something down the hall, under the legs of a telephone table. Gittes moves toward it. It is grotesque. When he gets closer he can see it's a wilted head of lettuce. Just inside the kitchen some radishes and onions lie on the linoleum. Gittes walks on into the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clearing the kitchen counter, Gittes sees IDA SESSIONS lying on her back on the floor, surrounded by the groceries from a broken bag. Ice cream has melted around her. Her eyes are open, a stream of ants is moving across the ice cream and into her mouth. She's recognizable as the woman who posed as Evelyn Mulwray. Gittes kneels over her. He gingerly opens her handbag, fishes for its contents, takes them and looks at them on the kitchen counter. Wallet with a few bills in it, driver's license with her name. A Screen Actors Guild card. Gittes nods, turns, carefully replaces the items in the purse. He idly opens the broom closet, pantry, and even Frigidaire, which is all but empty. Then he steps over her body and moves across the hall to a door that is slightly ajar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes enters and turns on the light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Escobar and another PLAINCLOTHED MAN stand in the bathroom by the entrance to the bedroom door. Gittes turns around. A THIRD MAN is now coming down the hall from the bedroom. Gittes looks at the two, doesn't reply.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Find anything interesting, Gittes?

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing here?

direction.raw_text: Escobar nods.

direction.raw_text: This is a little telling.

direction.raw_text: Escobar hesitates.

dialogue.raw_text: I heard it was an accident.

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, you think you're dealing with a bunch of assholes? Mulwray had salt water in his goddam lungs! Now how did he get that... in a fresh water reservoir?

dialogue.raw_text: You were following him night and day. You saw who killed him. You even took pictures of it. It was Evelyn Mulwray. She's been paying you off like a slot machine ever since her husband died.

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) You accusing me of extortion?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Absolutely.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't think I need a day or two. You're even dumber than you think I think you are. Not only that, I'd never extort a nickel out of my worst enemy, that's where I draw the line, Escobar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I once knew a whore who for enough money would piss in a customer's face, but she'd never shit on his chest. That's where she drew the line.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Well, I hope she wasn't too much of a disappointment to you, Lou.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want those photographs, Gittes. We're talking about accessory after the fact, conspiracy, and extortion. Minimum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why do you think Mulwray's body was moved you dimwit? Evelyn Mulwray knocked off her husband in the ocean and thought it would look like more of an accident if she hauled him up to the Oak Pass Reservoir?

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Mulwray was murdered and moved because somebody didn't want his body found in the ocean.

dialogue.raw_text: And why's that?

dialogue.raw_text: He found out somebody was dumping water there. That's what they were trying to cover up by moving him.

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon I'll show you.

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) C'mon make a decision, Lou. You're in charge.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might be able to squeeze an extra seventy-five bucks out of it for you. Maybe an even hundred.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Plus what I owe you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll throw that in too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Okay, you got yourself a boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Carry bags out to Curly's car. Curly opens the door for the Maid. She gets in. He turns to Gittes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curly nods, reassured. He gets in and takes off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell Mrs. Mulwray to wait for half an hour after you get there. Then if I don't show, take her down to the boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a little worried) You sure this is okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mildly indignant) Curly, you know how long I been in business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MULWRAY HOME  DUSK By the pond, cigarette smoke drifts INTO SHOT. A car pulls up. In a moment Cross can be SEEN, looking TOWARD CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks toward Gittes who stands by the pond, smoking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cross' tone alters here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes pulls something out of his pocket and unfolds it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cross dips into his coat pocket and pulls out a pair of rimless glasses.. He puts them on, reads.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (continuing) Well, you don't look any the worse for wear, Mr. Gittes, I must say... where's the girl?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is she all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With her mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...with her mother?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like you to look at something, Mr. Cross.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking it) What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: An obituary column... can you read in this light?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... I think I can manage...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Stares at the bifocal lenses as Cross continues to look through the obituary column. He looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes is holding the bifocals with the broken lens now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cross looks at the glasses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What does this mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That you killed Hollis Mulwray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right here, in this pond. You drowned him...  and you left these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...the coroner's report showed Mulwray had salt water in his lungs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (finally) Hollie was always fond of tide-pools. You know what he used to say about them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Haven't the faintest idea.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's where life begins... marshes, sloughs, tide-pools... he was fascinated by them...  you know when we first came out here he figured that if you dumped water onto desert sand it would percolate down into the bedrock and stay there, instead of evaporating the way it does in most reservoirs. You'd lose only twenty percent instead of seventy or eighty. He made this city.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And that's what you were going to do in the Valley?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: (after a long moment) No, Mr. Gittes. That's what I am doing with the Valley. The bond issue passes Tuesday. There'll be ten million to build an aqueduct and reservoir. I'm doing it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cross makes a funny little cock of his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mulvihill moves INTO VIEW. Extends his hand for the glasses. Gittes doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes hands over the glasses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There's going to be some irate citizens when they find out they're paying for water they're not getting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's all taken care of. You see, Mr. Gittes. Either you bring the water to L.A. or you bring L.A. to the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you do that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just incorporate the Valley into the city so the water goes to L.A. after all. It's very simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (then) How much are you worth?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shrugs, then) I have no idea. How much do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to know what you're worth. Over ten million?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why are you doing it? How much better can you eat? What can you buy that you can't already afford?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a long moment, then:) The future, Mr. Gittes. The future. Now where's the girl?... I want the only daughter I have left... as you found out, Evelyn was lost to me a long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (with sarcasm) Who do you blame for that? Her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't blame myself. You see, Mr. Gittes, most people never have to face the fact that at the right time and right place, they're capable of anything. Take those glasses from him, will you, Claude?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not worth it, Mr. Gittes. It's really not worth it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take us to the girl. Either Evelyn allows me to see her, or I'm not averse to seeing Evelyn in jail. If I have to buy the jail. Hollis and Evelyn kept her from me for fifteen years. It's been too long, I'm too old.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CHINATOWN STREET  NIGHT The streets are crowded. Here and there one can see Chinese in traditional dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Driving slowly, spots Katherine with Ramon and luggage, nearly lost in the crowd. They are walking toward a car parked near a laundry truck. Gittes sees them, keeps driving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mulvihill tries to clobber Gittes. Gittes elbows him. The car jumps the curb and hits a lamppost.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly) Stop the car. Stop the car!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Leaps out of the car shouting:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gittes is after him, grabbing him. Cross tries to swing at Gittes with his cane. Mulvihill comes up behind Gittes and the three of them begin an awkward wrestling match, the crowd scattering, Mulvihill pulling his revolver, trying to hit Gittes on the side of the head. The three men crash to the pavement.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Katherine! Katherine! Wait!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Starts out of the car toward Gittes. Gittes sees him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bites Mulvihill's hand and furiously pounds it into the sidewalk, shaking gun loose. Mulvihill and Gittes try for it but someone else has it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No, Curly, get 'em out of here! Get 'em out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue
